semantic-domain.question: What words refer to everything we can see? (universe, creation, cosmos, heaven and earth, macrocosm, everything that exists) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to refer to the sky? (sky, firmament, canopy, vault) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to the air around the earth? (air, atmosphere, airspace, stratosphere, ozone layer) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to refer to the place or area beyond the sky? (heaven, space, outer space, ether, void, solar system) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

semantic-domain.id: 7.1.9 Move a part of the body

(change (v), change (n), revise, revision, revolutionize, revolution, reform, reformation, modify, modification, develop, development, make different, impact, process, transform,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to a person who changes something? (revolutionary, reformer, radical) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words describe something that can be changed? (changeable) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words describe a big change? (big, major, sweeping, radical, fundamental, revolutionary, monumental,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words describe a small change? (small, slight, tiny, minute,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words describe a quick change? (quick, fast, rapid,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words describe a slow change? (slow, gradual,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate an event? (-ing, -'s...-ing, -ing...of, to,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What general words refer to a thing? (thing, something, article, artifact, entity, item, object, wares,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words refer to a group of things of different types? (things, oddments, paraphernalia, stuff, odds and ends, bits and pieces, knick-knacks,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to refer to something when you can't remember what it is called? (what's its name, thingy, thingamajig, whatchamacallit, whatsit, such and such) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to end a list of things to indicate that there are more things in the list? (et cetera, etc., and what not, and so forth, and the like, and on and on, ... [ellipsis]) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words describe something that is physical? (animal nature, biological, bodily, concrete, corporal, corporeal, earthly, earthy, fleshly, incarnate, inferior, matter, material, materialistic, mundane, natural, objective, physical, seen, sensible, sensual, tangible, temporal, unspiritual, worldly) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to something that is physical? (substance, stuff, matter, material) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words describe something that is non-physical? (disembodied, extramundane, extrasensory, immaterial, impalpable, incorporeal, instinctive, intangible, intellectual, libidinal, life, mental, metaphysical, nonphysical, nonmaterial, numinous, otherworldly, preternatural, psychic, psychological, rational, reasoning, spiritual, spiritualist, subjective, supernatural, transcendent, transcendental, unbodied, unearthly, unseen, unworldly,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to something that is non-physical? (spirit) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words refer to the general situation that exists in a place? (situation, things, conditions, state of affairs, set-up, context,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words refer to a situation that affects what can happen or what people can do? (situation, circumstances, environment, climate, conditions, the lay of the land, which way the wind blows, scenario,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words refer to a situation that exists at some time during a larger event or process? (situation, position, state of play,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words refer to the true situation rather than the situation that people think exists? (the picture, the score, what's going on,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to the situation a person is in? (situation, circumstances, position, case, plight,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something must happen or cannot happen because of the situation? (under the circumstances, in the circumstances, given the circumstances, given the situation, as it is, as things stand, force of circumstances, the way things are,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What general words can replace an adjective? (such, that kind of, that sort of,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What question words ask for an adjective in the answer? (what kind of, what sort of,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What question words ask for an ad-adjective in the answer? (how,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What general words can replace an adverb? (thus, thusly, so, how, like this, this way, in that way, in this manner) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What are the adjectives in your language? (young, big, good, black, kind, hot, fast,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What adverbs are in your language? (quickly) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What general words refer to the class of pronouns? (pronoun) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns refer to the speaker? (I, me, my, mine) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns refer to the speaker and those associated with the speaker? (we, us, our, ours) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns refer to the audience? (you, your, yours) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What pronouns refer to the people or things being spoken about? (he, him, his, she, her, hers, it, its, they, them, their, theirs) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns are used for the subject of a sentence? (I, you, he, she, it, we, you, they) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns are used for the object of a sentence? (me, you, him, her, it, us, you, them) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns are used in a possessive phrase? (my, your, his, her, its, our, your, their) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns are used in a possessive clause? (mine, yours, his, hers, its, ours, yours, theirs) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What pronouns are used to emphasize the people or things being spoken about, especially when you are emphasizing that one person does something and not someone else? (as for me (I), as for you (you), as for him (he), as for us (we), as for them (they)) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What pronouns express reflexive reference? (self, myself, yourself, himself, herself, itself, ourselves, yourselves, themselves, oneself) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns express reciprocal reference? (each other, one another) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What pronouns express indefinite reference of a person? (person, who, someone, anyone, everyone, no one, each one, whoever) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What pronouns express indefinite reference of a thing? (thing, what, something, anything, everything, nothing, each thing, whatever, whichever) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What pronouns express indefinite reference of a time? (time, period, when, sometime, anytime, every time, never, at no time, each time, whenever, sometimes) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What pronouns express indefinite reference of a place? (place, where, somewhere, anywhere, everywhere, nowhere, each place, wherever, which way) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What pronouns express indefinite reference of a reason? (reason, why, for what reason, for some reason, for any reason, for each and every reason, for no reason, why ever) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What pronouns express indefinite reference of a manner? (manner, means, how, somehow, anyhow, every way, no way, each way, however) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns express indefinite reference of an amount? (amount, how much, however many, however much, plenty) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns are used in relative clauses? (who, whom, that, which, why) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns are used in questions? (who, what, when, where, how, why) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns are used to indicate a particular referent? (a, an, the, this, these, that, those, specific,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to indicate that you do something yourself, rather than through someone else? (personally, in person, direct) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to indicate that you make something yourself rather than using a machine? (by hand) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What prepositions are in your language? (in, on, at, from, to, away, toward, about,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What conjunctions are in your language? (and, or, but,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What conjunctions join two words within a phrase? (and, both...and, or, either...or, neither...nor, but,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What conjunctions join two clauses? (and, or, while, then, if, because,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What conjunctions join two sentences? (then, so,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What particles are in your language? (He lives <just> across the street.) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate the class of something? ((Japanese) -hon (long objects), -mai (flat objects), -ban (order in a series), -nin (people), -fun (minutes), -dai (large vehicles)) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What interjections are in your language? (Wow! Hold on! Good grief!) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What idiophones are in your language? (knick-knack, flimflam) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What affixes are in your language? (-s, -ed, -ing) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What affixes can be joined to verbs? (-ing, -ed, -s) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What affixes can be joined to nouns? (-s, -en) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What derivational affixes are there? (un-, a-, self-, super-, -ment, -hood, -ous, -ly, -fy) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words intensify an attribute? (very, really, highly, deeply, real, so, mighty, one, quite, ever so, bloody, decidedly, too, proper, true, extremely, such) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words intensify an attribute to an extreme degree? (extremely, terribly, dreadfully, incredibly, unbelievably, ridiculously, absurdly, remarkably, exceptionally, extraordinarily, terrifically, enormously, hugely, exceedingly,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that an attribute is not intense? (not very, hardly, barely, a little, fairly) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to the degree of something? (degree, extent, level, thus) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate a degree on a scale? (high, low, greater, lesser, first, primary, secondary,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to a marked extent? (up to, as much as, to the degree that) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to a change in degree? (fluctuate, fluctuation, move, vary,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words express a comparative degree? (more, -er) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words express a superlative degree? (most, -est) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate a large degree? (large, great, major, considerable, large scale, huge, enormous, immense, tremendous, high, advanced, rich,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to a large degree? (size, magnitude,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate a small degree? (deficient, inappreciably, inconsequentially, insignificantly, lacking, lightly, limited, little, low, merely, moderately, negligibly, piddling, possible, puny, reasonably, relatively, slightly, somewhat, sparingly, temperately, trivial, trivially,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something is becoming larger in degree? (advance, double, explode, gain, grow, increase, jump, rise, rocket, soar, triple,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to the amount by which something became larger? (growth, explosion, hike, increase, rise,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to causing something to become larger in degree? (increase, raise, swell) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that something is larger than another thing in degree? (more than,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something is becoming smaller in degree? (decline, decrease, diminish, drop, dwindle, fall, plummet, slide, tumble,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to the amount by which something became smaller? (decline (n), decrease, fall, reduction, tumble) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to causing something to become smaller in degree? (decrease, lower, reduce,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that something is smaller than another thing in degree? (less than, lower,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something is done to a complete degree? (completely, fully, totally, entirely, wholly, absolutely, utterly, positively, in every way, in every respect, in every sense, through and through, whole-heartedly, altogether, out-and-out, outright, perfect, perfectly, roundly, solid, solidly, thoroughly, unmitigated, unqualified, utter,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What general words refer to all of something's attributes or manners? (completely, in every way,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words describe something that is done completely? (complete, thorough, full, comprehensive, exhaustive, entire,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something is done partly? (partly, partially, to some extent, to a certain extent, to a degree, to some degree, up to a point, in part, sort of,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something is done one part at a time? (gradually, in stages, step by step, one step at a time, in increments, incrementally, piecemeal, by degrees, little by little,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to indicate that something is being done intensely? (intense, intensely, extensively) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words modify an attribute? (fairly, sort of, quite,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
present: the situation occurs simultaneously with the moment of speech.
past: the situation occurred before the moment of speech.
future: the situation takes place after the moment of speech; the speaker predicts that the situation in the proposition will hold.
crastinal: tomorrow.
hesternal: yesterday.
hodiernal: today, normally with past.
pre-hodiernal: before today.
post-crastinal: after tomorrow.
ancient past: used for narrating events in ancient or mythical time.
remote: combines with other tense labels to indicate a situation occurring temporally distant from the moment of speech.
immediate: a meaning label that may be combined with other tense labels to indicate a situation not simultaneous with the moment of speech, but very close to it.
immediate future: what is about to occur.
immediate past: occurring immediately before the moment of speech. Also called the Recent Past. Do not use this label if there is any sense of current relevance--use anterior for that.
Immediate may also be combined with anterior or imperative.
expected future: the situation is to occur in the near future; what is scheduled to happen.
narrative time: the use of a form with no other past uses for reporting a past narrative.
gnomic present: the situation described in the proposition is generic; the predicate has held, holds, and will hold for the class of entities named by the subject, such as 'Elephants have trunks'.
What general words refer to the tense of an event? (tense, time) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to indicate the present tense? ((no words or affixes in English)) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to indicate the past tense? (-ed, (in English vowel replacement is also used to indicate past tense, e.g. run, ran)) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to indicate the future tense? (will, going to) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
habitual: the situation is customary or usual, repeated on different occasion over a period of time. English 'used to' is past habitual; English 'Nancy sings' is present habitual.

continuous: a single situation is viewed as in progress, as maintained over a period of time; also called "durative." The English "Progressive" is a continuous restricted to dynamic words. English 'I am reading; *I am knowing the number'.
continuative: keep on doing what is being done. Restricted to dynamic words.

progressive: the action takes place simultaneously with the moment of reference, 'to be in the process of...'. This is more restricted than the English Progressive, which may be used for events that are not actually in progress at reference time: 'I am writing a book' may be used even if the speaker is not at that moment writing.
excessive duration: action is extended over a long period of time, longer than normal for that action.
limited duration: action performed for a relatively short or bounded period of time.
iterative: the action is repeated on one occasion; usually restricted to dynamic words, often further restricted to semelfactive words.
frequentative: action occurs frequently, not necessarily habitually, nor necessarily on one occasion, as is the iterative.
imperfective: the situation is viewed as unbounded in the sense that it is habitual, continuous, progressive, or iterative.
perfective: the situation is viewed as bounded temporally. It cannot be simultaneous with the moment of speech; in the non-past it is sometimes interpreted as future.
completive: to do something thoroughly and to completion, e.g. 'to shoot someone dead, to eat up'.
inceptive: the action or event begins. We are distinguishing this from the beginning of a state.
delimited: action is performed only a little.
The preceding terms or "Aspects" are not usually relevant to stative words.
What general words refer to an aspect of an event? (aspect) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to indicate that something has begun? (begin, start, commence, beginning, the start, commencement, initiate, to institute, inception) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What do people say when they want someone else to start? (go, dig in, have at it, let's go, let's do it, move it, let's get going, "on your marks, get set, go", "ready, set, go") Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What is a person called who starts something? (initiator, founder, originator, starter) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to indicate that someone is attempting to do something? (try, attempt) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to indicate that something is being done quickly? (quick, quickly, rapidly) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to indicate that something happened suddenly? (sudden, suddenly, suddenness, immediate) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to indicate something is continuing? (continue, continuous, keep on) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to indicate that something has been completed? (complete, finish, succeed) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
state exists: the state is begun before reference time and continues after reference time. (is,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

state commences: beginning of a state of "becoming." Often called Inceptive or Inchoative. If there is a morpheme specifically for this meaning, it is usually derivational and restricted to stative words. However, it is also possible for "Perfects" or "Perfectives" to have this as their use with stative words. (becoming,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

state ends: state existed in the past, but no longer exists. Also a possible meaning of "Perfects" or "Perfectives" in combination with stative words. (no longer,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
state continues: state is continuing a reference time. (still,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
state changes: (self-explanatory). (turn,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
resulting state (resultative): action in the past produces a state that persists into the present. (be... -en,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

anterior continuing: past action continues into the present: 'I have waited over an hour' ( = and I'm still waiting). (have been... -ing,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

anterior: the situation occurs prior to reference time, and is relevant to the situation at reference time. This is different from a simple past or perfective, where the situation is reported for its own sake and independent of its relevance to any other situation. (have... -en,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

A form that signals a situation that is prior to and relevant to a past reference time will be coded with two meaning labels, past and anterior. (had... -en,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
ability: the agent of the verb has the mental or physical ability to complete the action of the main verb.
ability, mental: English: 'Melissa can speak Dutch'. (can,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
ability, physical: English: 'Hortense can swim the English Channel'. (can,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

attempt: the agent attempts to complete the action specified by the predicate. Note: this has a sense of incompleteness, and I have seen authors call this "Incomplete" and gloss the examples with 'try'. (try to, attempt to,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
desire: the agent of the verb desires or wants to complete the action of the verb. (want to, would like to,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
obligation: the agent is obliged to perform the action of the verb.

obligation, strong: it is absolutely incumbent upon the agent to complete the action of the main verb: 'I have to mail this letter today'. (have to, must,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

obligation, weak: it is recommended that the agent complete the action of the main verb: 'Harry ought to get a haircut before meeting Sue's mother'. (ought to, should,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

permission: the agent is allowed to complete the action of the main verb: 'The students may check books out for two weeks'. (may,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

root possibility: it is possible for the agent to carry out the action of the main verb; i.e. s/he is able and external conditions allow it: 'You can get that kind of paper at Ulbrich's'. (can,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

intention: the agent intends to carry out the action of the main verb: 'Sam's gonna take Sanskrit next semester'. (gonna, going to, intend to,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

andative: agent moves away from the deictic center in order to do something, literally 'be going to do something'. Of course such forms are often related to the verb 'to go' and also may have uses of intention and future. (go to,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

venitive: the agent moves toward the deictic center in order to do something, literally 'be coming to do something'. This may be related to the verb 'to come' and may have future uses as well. (come to,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that someone is able to do something? (can, know how to, be able to, have the ability to, capable,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to the ability of someone to do something? (ability, capability, prowess,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that someone is not able to do something? (inability, unable, incapable,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words describe a person's inability to do a job? (can't do something, not be able to do something, cannot, be incapable of, not be capable of, be unable to do something, someone's inability to do something, incompetent, unqualified, unfitted, untrained, not be equipped, be ill-equipped, powerless,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words refer to a person's inability to do a job? (incapacity, incompetence, inability, deficiency, lack of training) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that something is necessary? (must, need to, have to, have got to) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words describe something that is necessary? (necessary, compulsory, essential, imperative, indispensable, inevitable, mandatory, obligatory, required, unavoidable, urgent, vital,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to something that is necessary? (necessity, need, obligation, prerequisite, requirement,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words describe something that is not necessary? (unnecessary, extraneous, incidental, inessential, needless, nonessential, uncalled-for, unessential, unnecessary, unneeded,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

imperative: the verb form used for direct commands in the 2nd person. If there are also 1st and 3rd person forms, the meaning can still be that of imperative, with the 1st and 3rd persons being interpreted as 'Let us, let him...', etc.
optative: the proposition represents the speaker's will. Translated into English as 'May you prosper', 'May we all meet again.' with counterfactual: 'If only he had...', etc.
hortative: the speaker is encouraging or inciting someone to action.
prohibitive: the mood for expressing negative commands. The English is 'Don't'.
admonitive: the command constitutes a warning: 'you had better not...'.
Meanings co-occurring with imperative:
polite: a mild or polite form of command.
delayed: the action of the command is to be carried out in the future rather than immediately.
immediate: the action of the command is to be carried out immediately.
strong: (self-explanatory).
What words indicate that the sentence is a command? ((none in English)) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What affixes indicate that the sentence is a command? ((none in English), (in many Bantu languages) -e 'a verbal suffix indicating that the sentence is a command') Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are only used in the imperative? (whoa (stop)) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that the speaker is encouraging or inciting someone to action. (urge, request, let, why don't, please) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that something should be done? (should, ought to, be responsible for, be duty bound,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that something should not be done? (should not, ought not to, caution) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to something a person should do? (duty, responsibility, obligation, onus, requirement,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words describe the person who should do something? (responsible,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words describe someone who does what he should? (dutiful, responsible) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that the sentence is a question? ((Japanese) ka? 'a particle coming at the end of a sentence to indicate that it is a question') Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
English has an interjection that is added to a statement that has the effect of questioning something about it.

possibility: the speaker is indicating that the situation described in the proposition is possibly true. Some markers with this meaning also indicate future time: 'He may arrive late because of the weather; It may snow again tomorrow; She could have already taken it'. (may, could,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

probability: the speaker is indicating that the situation described in the proposition is probably true. Some marker with this meaning also indicate future time. This is sometimes called the "Dubitative" in grammars: 'Paula should be home by now'. (should,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

inferred certainty: the speaker infers from evidence that the proposition is true: 'They must have killed a bear here (I can see blood on the snow)'. (must have,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
certainty: the speaker is emphasizing that the proposition is true. (certainly,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
uncertainty: the speaker is emphasizing that s/he doesn't know that the proposition is true. (might,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

indicative: main clause mood that also appears in questions. Contrasts with subjunctive, conditional, and imperative. ([none in English]) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something is certainly true? (certainly, absolutely, definitely, there is no doubt, undoubtedly, without a doubt, without doubt, without a shadow of a doubt, unquestionably, be beyond dispute, there's no denying, there are no two ways about it, there is no question) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something will certainly happen? (certainly, definitely, be bound to, be sure to, be certain to, be assured of, be only a matter of time, be just a matter of time, cut and dried, you can bet your life, you can bet your bottom dollar, be a certainty, be a foregone conclusion, for sure) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something will certainly succeed? (can't go wrong, be a dead cert, it's in the bag, it's a safe bet, it's a sure bet, foolproof) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words refer to doing something in order to be certain that something will happen? (make sure, make certain, insure, ensure, see that, see to it) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that maybe something may happen or is true? (maybe, perhaps, may, might, it is possible, possibly, could, who knows?, there's a chance, you never know, conceivably,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that someone or something is not what it seems to be? (there's more to someone/something than meets the eye, deceptive, deceptively, not be what you/it seem,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to what you think or feel because of what someone or something seems? (impression, feeling,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to the way something seems to appear? (appearance, semblance of,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that although something is true, it almost is not true? (just, almost didn't, nearly didn't, only just, narrowly, barely,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that something bad almost happened, but it did not? (narrowly missed, close shave) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that you did something, but almost didn't do it? (just, only just, barely, be a near thing, be a close thing, by the skin of your teeth) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that you can do something, but it is difficult? (can hardly, can barely, can scarcely) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that something is a particular amount, but not much more? (just, only just, barely) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that you think it is very unlikely that something is true or will happen? (don't think, doubt, be doubtful, be dubious, I'd be surprised if, I think not, I wouldn't have thought so) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something cannot be done? (impossible, not possible, impracticable, there's no way, out of the question, hopeless, impractical) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that your situation makes it impossible for you to do something? (impossible, not have a hope, not stand a chance, can't possibly, that's out, with the best will in the world, do the impossible) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something cannot happen? (impossible, not possible, can't, couldn't, impossibility, inconceivable, unthinkable, by any/no stretch of the imagination, there's no way) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that something is impossible to get? (unattainable, out of reach) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that one thing makes something else impossible? (make something impossible, rule out, preclude) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something is impossible? (absurd, impenetrable, impervious, inaccessible, inoperable, insurmountable, no chance, no earthly way, outlandish, preposterous, ridiculous, unable, unachievable, unapproachable, undoable, unfeasible, unimaginable, unworkable,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

direct evidence: the speaker claims to have witnessed the situation, but does not specify the type of sensory evidence. (I was there and...,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
visual evidence: the speaker claims to have seen the situation described. (with my own eyes I saw...,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
auditory evidence: the speaker claims to have heard the situation described. (with my own ears I heard...,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

sensory evidence: the speaker claims to have physically sensed the situation described. This can be in opposition to one or both of the above senses (i.e. any other sense), or it can indicate sensory evidence that is not further specified (i.e. any sensory evidence).

indirect evidence: the speaker claims not to have witnessed the situation, but does not specify further whether the evidence is reported or simply inferred. (I wasn't there but...,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

reported evidence: the speaker claims to know of the situation described via verbal means, but does not specify whether it is second-hand, hearsay, or via folklore. (I heard that...,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
second-hand evidence: the speaker claims to have heard of the situation described from someone who was a direct witness.

evidence from hearsay: the speaker claims to have heard about the situation described, but not from a direct witness. (it is rumored that...,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

evidence from folklore: the speaker claims that the situation described is part of established oral history (e.g., mythology). (according to our ancestors...,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
inferred evidence: the speaker infers the event/action, but does not specify whether the inference is based on observable results or on a purely mental process.

inference from results: the speaker infers the situation described from the evidence at hand (i.e. from the observable results of the causing event/action.) (from the results I would say...,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

inference from reasoning: the speaker infers the situation described on the basis of intuition, logic, a dream, previous experience, or some other mental construct. (I figure that..., I conclude that...,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate who is evaluating the proposition? (to, in my opinion,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that you heard what you are saying from someone else? (according to, rumor has it, they say, people say, there is talk of, apparently, supposedly, be rumored to be,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to affirm the truth of something? (yes, yeah, yea, indeed, true, that's true, it is true, verily, agreed, certainly, of course, that's right, I guess so, that is so, a-huh, nod your head, affirmative, positive) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to refer to the action of affirming the truth of something? (affirm, affirmation, confirm, concur, agree, agreement) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to negate the truth of something? (no, none, not, nay, uh-uh, no one, nothing, never, nowhere, no indeed, by no means, certainly not, most certainly not, absolutely not, shake your head, negative) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to refer to the process of denying the truth of something? (deny, denial, negate, negation, disavow, disavowal, contradict, contradiction, repudiate, repudiation) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What are the noun forms of these words?
What words are used to indicate that an affirmative answer is expected to a question? (n't,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to indicate that a negative answer is expected to a question? (n't...are you,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

subordinating: Often there are special verb forms or morphemes associated with the verb that occur obligatorily in subordinate clauses of certain types. The extent to which such morphemes can be said to have "meaning" varies, since they often co-occur with other markers of subordination. Their function is primarily to signal the type of subordinate clause.

Complement clauses: A main verb may take as its direct object a clause. These are often referred to as "Noun clauses" or "Noun complements". The verb form of the subordinate clause is usually determined by the semantics of the main verb, so in this case, our meaning labels will just refer to the context. If a verb form occurs in the complements to words of thinking and believing, the meaning label will be complement to words of thinking and believing.
complement to words of thinking
complement to words of believing
complement to words of saying
complement to words of ordering (in English we use an infinitive with these words)
complement to words of wanting (again in English these are done with infinitives)
complement to words of emotion (surprise, regret, happiness, sadness, etc.; the complement proposition is presupposed to be true)
complement to words of obligation
complement to words of admonition
subsequent: following a reference time in the past.
subordinator: marker indicates that the verb is in a subordinate clause.

There are a variety of adverbial clauses (other than conditional clauses) that sometimes require a special verb form. The meaning labels for these uses are coded according to the type of clause (purpose, concessive, etc.), whether any particular temporal deixis is part of the meaning, and under "co-occurrence restrictions," whether a particular conjunction is present. The types of clauses we might run into are:

purpose: the clause states the purpose for which the main clause action is taking place. Often called a "final" clause: 'He was saving his money so that his son could go to college'. (so that) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

concessive: translated in English as 'although, even though, despite the fact that': 'She was saving her money, even though she was a wealthy woman'. (although, even though, despite the fact that) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

(cause, reason, source, because, because of, for this reason, for the above reasons, for the following reasons, first cause, origin, breed (v), gives birth to, due to, owing to, thus) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that something is reasonable? (reasonable) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words reason why someone does something? (reason, motive, motivation) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to a reason that explains why something happened? (reason, explanation,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something has no cause or reason? (without cause, unreasonable, without basis, absurd, for no reason, by itself) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that something is contrary to reason? (contrary to reason, absurd) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that something is self-caused?

What words indicate the result of something? (result, outcome, end, to result in, to lead to, wages, to end up being, have as a consequence, therefore, so then, consequently, as a result, for this reason, with the result that, so that as a result, to cause, which caused, so that, that, accordingly, then, hence, and so, yield, has the effect of) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that something had no result? (without result, without effect, in vain, to no avail, with no result, have no discernable effect, pointless, useless, worthless, be left with nothing, not yield) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate the intended purpose of something? (for, for the purpose of, for the sake of, with the purpose of, to, in order to, so that, to show that,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words indicate that the purpose is so that something will not happen? (in order that...not, so that...not, lest) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that there is no purpose to an action? (without purpose, for no purpose, in vain, purposeless, senseless, chance, indiscriminate, meaningless, pointless, undirected,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

Conditional sentences: Conditional sentences consist of two clauses, the 'if'-clause or protasis (which is a subordinate clause) and the 'then'-clause or apodosis (which is the main clause). Both of these clauses may take special verb forms. (Interestingly enough, they sometime both take the same special verb forms.)

There are at least three types of conditional sentences. (Labels, explanations, and examples from Li and Thompson 1981): [Li, Charles N., and Sandra A. Thompson. 1981. Mandarin Chinese: A functional reference grammar. Berkeley and Los Angeles: University of California Press.]
reality condition: a conditional relation between two propositions referring to the so-called real world: 'If you see my sister, you will know that she is pregnant'.
hypothetical: the situation is unreal or imagined, but one that could be true: 'If we moved, we could have a garden'.
counterfactual: the proposition describes an unreal or imagined situation that could have been true but was not: 'If you had taken algebra, you would know this formula' (but you did not).
The verb forms that occur in these sentences will be coded according to the type of sentence, and according to which clause of the sentence they occur in.
Example: the English 'had' + past participle would be coded as:
meaning label: protasis
meaning label: counterfactual
Since the conjunction 'if' obligatorily occurs in the protasis, there will also be the following:
Co-occurrence restriction: 'if'
This indicates that a morpheme meaning 'if' obligatorily occurs in the protasis. If no such morpheme is necessary, then there will be no co-occurrence restriction.

What words indicate the condition of a conditional sentence? (condition, if, if indeed, if at all, whether...or, or else, otherwise, unless) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that the speaker is conceding a point? (concession, although, though, even though, and yet, even if, nevertheless) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What discourse markers are in your language? (just, you know, OK, yeah, like) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to join two clauses or sentences without specifying the relationship between them? (and, then, but, now, it happened that, it came to pass that, one day, my next topic is, my next point is, now about) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words indicate that a phrase or sentence is important? (then, indeed, surely, so, certainly, in fact, actually, how, you know, really, sure, just, you know don't you that, how much more, emphatically, absolutely, without question, no way, of course, obviously, you've got to be kidding, it is just that, the only thing is, one thing that, in reality, only that, as it were, just as you can see, as you know, without a doubt, don't you remember, I am convinced that) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to get someone's attention? (you, you there, hey you, hello, excuse me, attention, attention please, may I have your attention please, pay attention, listen up everybody, now hear this, and now for an important announcement, and now for a word from our sponsor, just a moment, wait a minute, lend me your ears, look here, ahem) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to direct someone's attention to something? (behold, look, will you look at that, get a load of this, (point)) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to warn someone of danger? (watch out, look out, heads up, hit the dirt, get out of the way, here it comes, oh no, (scream)) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What non-verbal means are used to get someone's attention (clear throat, whistle, raise hand) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used when you start talking to someone? (O, sir, ma'am, ladies and gentlemen, men and brothers, (look) you, (listen) all of you) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

semantic-domain.id: 9.6.3.5 Markers of identificational and explanatory clauses
semantic-domain.question: What words are used to identify a specific case? (that, namely, namely that, that is, i.e.) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to introduce an example? (for example, e.g., as follows, as below, such as, let me give you an example, to illustrate) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to introduce an explanation? (what I mean is, that is to say, let me add, allow me to explain, it's like) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used to introduce a conclusion? (which shows that, so we find, so we see) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words mark a digression? (let me just insert, as an aside, this is off the subject, oh by the way) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words focus especially on one of several things? (especially, particularly, particular, most of all) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used when a speaker hesitates or pauses to think? (um, uh, er, hmm, yeah, let's see, hold on a minute, let me see, let me think) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What pronouns are used to show respect or a lack of respect? (thou (archaic), you (archaic),) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What affixes are used to show respect? ((none in English)) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What particles are used to show respect? (please,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What terms of direct address are used to show respect? (sir, ma'am, your honor, your majesty,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used in greetings to show respect? (hey, hi, hello, pleased to meet you,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used in requests to show respect? (may, can,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words are used in apologies to show respect? (sorry, excuse me, I beg your pardon,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What general words refer to the name of a person, place, or thing? (name, proper noun,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to giving a name to someone or something? (name (v), call, christen,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words refer to the name of a person? (name, proper name, proper noun, first name, given name, personal name, middle name, last name, family name, father's name, surname, maiden name, initial, title, identity,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words refer to a name your family or friends use for you that is not your real name? (nickname, pet name) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words refer to a name you use for yourself that is not your real name? (false name, pseudonym, pen name, stage name, alias, a.k.a. (also known as), under the name of, under an assumed name, go by the name of,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to refer to someone when you can't remember what they are called? (what's his/her name, whatchamacallit, whatsit, so and so,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
What words describe someone whose name is not known? (anonymous, unnamed, unidentified, incognito, unknown, nameless,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words are used to indicate a person's name? (someone's name is, be called, be known as, named,) Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.

What words refer to giving someone a name? (name (v), call, be christened, give a name to, choose a name, pick a name, call him/her 'name') Do not just translate these words; instead think of words in your own language.
